questions.question: A young lady who presented with oligomenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed with PCOS.Mutation of which of the following genes can cause this condition?
A teenage girl presented with complaints of excessive growth of coarse hair on her jawlineand upper lip. Which of the following is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical history of excessive growth of coarse hair is suggestive of hirsutism. The mostcommon cause for hirsutism in female patients is polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).Hirsutism is defined as excessive growth of androgen-dependent sexual hair or male distributionof hair in female patients. PCOS accounts for 70-80% of the cases of hirsutism, which typicallybegins in late adolescence or the early 20s.Idiopathic hirsutism is the second most frequent cause. The most common rapid onset ofhirsutism in young females is a testosterone-producing tumour like granulosa cell orSertoli-Leydig cell tumours.•Other less common causes of hirsutism include:⚫ Late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia•Tumours of the ovary and adrenal gland• Cushing's syndrome• Drug-inducedVirilisation: Characterized by more extensive androgen-induced changes than hirsutism alone. Ithas the following features:••Acne• Increased oily skin•Temporal balding• Clitoromegaly•• Deepening of the voice• Development of male muscular pattern and body habitus•Atrophy of breastsHypertrichosis: Excessive growth of non-sexual hair.

questions.question: A mother brought her 15-year-old daughter to the OPD with concerns of excessive growth ofcoarse hair over her face and chest. Which scoring system is used to clinically grade thiscondition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hirsutism. The Ferriman-Gallwey score is used toclinically assess and quantify the degree of hirsutism.Within this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed at nine body areas and each of themscored from 0-4. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a givenarea. The maximum score is 36. The degree of hirsutism is mild if the score is ≥8. Moderate to663severe hirsutism is present if the score is ≥15.Note: Ferriman Gallwey score originally had 11 sites which were modified later to exclude 2 sites,viz., forearm, and legs.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is the Rotterdam criteria used to diagnose?657
questions.explanation: The Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose Stein-Levinthal syndrome or PCOS.ESHRE/ASRM or Rotterdam criteria (2003):Any two out of these three must be present-•Clinical Biochemical hyperandrogenism• Oligo/anovulation•Polycystic ovaries•Other criteria used for diagnosing PCOS:•• National Institute of Health (NIH) criteria (1990)To include both• Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism• Oligo/anovulation• Androgen excess and PCOS society (AE-PCOS) criteria:•• To include both:• Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism• Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovariesOption A: Meig's syndrome refers to ascites and pleural effusions that accompany a benignovarian tumor.Option B: Asherman's syndrome refers to the formation of intrauterine synechiae, usuallyfollowing endometrial destructive procedures like curettage or ablation.Option C: Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome is characterised by congenital absence ofvagina, primary amenorrhoea, rudimentary cornua uteri and morphologically normal ovaries andFallopian tubes situated on the pelvic sidewall.

questions.question: An adolescent girl was brought by her mother to the clinic with complaints of irregularperiods and acne. A USG scan was performed which showed the following finding. Which ofthe following is the most likely diagnosis?SPTAO 21M2SeDB C6 E4HD1.2->2.0-5.0-2:54 cm
questions.explanation: The given clinical history and the necklace appearance on ultrasound are suggestive of polycysticovarian disease.The original Rotterdam consensus defined polycystic ovaries when ≥12 follicles were seen perovary on USG. Each follicle should measure between 2 and 9 mm, and/or an ovarian volumeshould be >10 ml. Due to improvement in imaging modalities since that time, the threshold for664follicle number has now been raised to 20 per ovary.

questions.question: A 26-year-old woman who presented with complaints of irregular cycles and weight gain wasdiagnosed with PCOS. This condition is characterised by multiple ovarian cysts that are lessthanin size.
questions.explanation: PCOS is characterised by multiple small ovarian cysts, each less than 1 cm in size.Sonographic findings seen in PCOS are:••≥ 12 small cysts of 2 to 9 mm in diameter.• Increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both.A single ovary with these findings is sufficient to define PCOS. However, this criteria does notapply to women taking combined oral contraceptive pills.Note: In settings with improved sonographic imaging resolution, a follicle number ≥ 20 cysts perovary can be considered significant for PCOS.

questions.question: A 29-year-old lady presented to your clinics with lesions as shown in the below images. Whichof the following is a false statement regarding her condition?
questions.explanation: The hyperpigmented areas in the given image are acanthosis nigricans and this is associated withhyperinsulinemia. This skin condition is thought to be a cutaneous marker of insulin resistance.Acanthosis nigricans is a velvety, darkening of the skin that usually occurs in the intertriginousareas. It has poorly defined borders, usually occurs in skin fold areas, such as the back of the neck,axilla, and groin, and may include thickening of the skin.The pathogenesis of acanthosis nigricans is linked to growth factor levels and insulin-mediatedactivation of insulin-like growth factor (IGF) on keratinocytes and increased growth factor levels.Acanthosis nigricans is usually seen in people younger than 40 years of age and is associated withthe following disorders:•Obesity⚫ Hypothyroidism• Acromegaly•.•Polycystic ovary disease• Insulin-resistant diabetes• Cushing's disease•• Addison's disease• Gastrointestinal malignancies such as adenocarcinoma of the stomach or pancreas.The treatment for acanthosis nigricans is directed towards the management of the underlyingcause.665

questions.question: A 25-year-old female patient presented with hirsutism. After further evaluation, a diagnosis ofHAIR-AN syndrome was made. Which of the following statements is false regarding thiscondition?
questions.explanation: HAIR-AN syndrome is not characterized by mild hyperandrogenism but markedhyperandrogenism (HA). It also includes insulin resistance (IR) and acanthosis nigricans (AN).HAIR-AN syndrome and ovarian hyperthecosis are exaggerated phenotypes of polycystic ovariansyndrome (PCOS). Women affected by HAIR-AN syndrome often present with symptoms ofsevere hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne) and may occasionally display signs of virilization likeclitoromegaly, temporal balding and voice deepening.Ovarian hyperthecosis is a rare condition characterized by nests of luteinized theca cellsdistributed throughout the ovarian stroma.

questions.question: 659A young lady being evaluated for infertility is diagnosed to have PCOS. Which of the followinglab findings would you not expect to see in her?

options.B: Testosterone levels elevated but < 200 ng/dLRaised LDL levelsd) Raised HDL levelsQuestion 10:A teenage girl who recently got diagnosed with PCOS presented with skin lesions on herforehead as shown in the image below. On examination, hirsutism was also noted. Which ofthe following drugs would you prescribe to this patient?a) Letrozoleb) OCPs with cyproterone acetate

questions.explanation: A depressed HDL level and elevated total cholesterol:HDL ratios are seen in patients with PCOS.The following are associated with PCOS:•• Insulin resistance• Impaired glucose tolerance and type 2 diabetes mellitus•Dyslipidemia: Increased LDL and triglyceride levels, elevated total cholesterol levels: HDL ratios.Infertility/subfertility• A three-fold increased risk of endometrial cancer•Mild elevations in testosterone levels <200 ng/dLNormal range of testosterone in women is 20-70 ng/dL. A mild elevation in testosterone isconsistent with the diagnosis of PCOS. However, values > 200 ng/dL may suggest an ovariantumour and warrant pelvic sonography.

questions.question: A 31-year-old lady has been unable to conceive for the past 2 years in spite of regularintercourse. She has recently been diagnosed with PCOS. Which of the following is the FDAapproved medication that you could recommend to her?660
questions.explanation: Clomiphene is an FDA approved drug used for the treatment of infertility associated with PCOS.Clomiphene induces ovulation in 80% of the cases and 40-50% patients conceive. However,abortions are common due to luteal phase defects. Ovarian hyperstimulation occurs in <1%cases. Co-administration with dexamethasone leads to better outcomes. In resistant case,tamoxifen 20-40 mg daily for 5 days should be tried.Currently, letrozole has proven to be more effective in ovarian infertility in obese women but itsuse in such cases is pending FDA approval.

questions.question: In a patient diagnosed with PCOS, which of the following is not an indication for surgicalmanagement?
questions.explanation: Surgical management is indicated in all the above conditions except for morbid obesity.Indications of surgery in PCOS include:• Failed medical therapy• Ovarian hyperstimulation•Infertility• Previous pregnancy losses.Surgery comprises of laparoscopic drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary.It is done using a laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine milieu andimproves fertility for a year or so. Thereafter, pelvic adhesions caused by surgery may againreduce the fertility rate. The formation of adhesions can be reduced by hydrofloatation.The advantages of surgery are as follows:•⚫ Tubal testing with chromotubation can be performed simultaneously• Other causes of infertility like endometriosis can be looked for• One-time treatment• Intense and prolonged monitoring for side effects is not required• Cost-effective compared to IVF• Reduces androgen and LH production667• Following surgery, single ovulation occurs with drugs, and hyperstimulation and multiplepregnancies are avoided• Ovulation occurs in 80-90% and pregnancy in 60-70%The disadvantages of surgery are as follows:• It involves giving anaesthesia and performing an invasive procedure like laparoscopy• Adhesions may form postoperatively.• If cautery is used, premature ovarian failure due to destruction of ovarian tissue may be seen

questions.question: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with human menopausal gonadotropin.She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?560Left ovaryRight Ovary

options.D: NoneUterusGn 8C5/M6FF2/63SRIII 4 CRI 41 D 61.7mm2 D 53.1mm3 D 60.3mm4 D 57.5mm661

questions.explanation: The image showing enlarged ovaries with multiple large cysts along with the history of treatmentfor infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin suggests the diagnosis of ovarianhyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).Human menopausal gonadotropin (HMG) is a medication that is composed of FSH and LH. It isused to stimulate the release of ova in women who do not ovulate spontaneously. It can leadto ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is a condition associated with ovarian enlargementdue to exogenous gonadotropin therapy. Symptoms include abdominal pain, distention, ascites,gastrointestinal problems, respiratory compromise, oliguria, and thromboembolism. It can occurduring ovulation induction or in early pregnancies conceived through exogenous ovarianstimulation.Predisposing factors for OHSS include multi-follicular ovaries (such as in PCOS), young age, highestradiol levels during ovulation induction, and pregnancy.Vasoactive substances produced by the corpus luteum, such as vascular endothelial growth factor(VEGF) and angiotensin II, are believed to contribute to enhanced capillarypermeability, resulting in the loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity andhemoconcentration.Sonographic examination reveals enlarged ovaries with numerous follicular cysts and ascites.Maintaining fluid balance with isotonic fluids like normal saline is crucial. Strategies to preventOHSS during exogenous ovulation include reducing follicular stimulation (low FSH dose),coasting (withholding FSH administration one or more days prior to the hCG trigger),prophylactic volume expanders, and substituting hCG for FSH towards the end of ovarianstimulation.Other options:Option B: Theca lutein cysts are a rare form of follicular cysts characterized by luteinization andhypertrophy of the theca interna layer. Both ovaries are enlarged and cystic. This condition iscommonly associated with gestational trophoblastic disease, multifetal gestation, andplacentomegaly.Option C: Polycystic ovarian syndrome shows 12 or more small follicles each 2-9 mm in sizeplaced peripherally (necklace pattern) (shown below). The patient presents with menstrual668irregularities, hirsutism, acne, etc.Page: 5 of 5CIM: 30

questions.question: A 21-year-old nulliparous woman presented with galactorrhoea and breast engorgement.Which of the following is a false statement regarding this condition?

options.A: Prolactin is the most important hormone involved in its pathophysiology
options.B: Prolactin levels more than 25 ng/ml cause this condition
options.C: All patients with hyperprolactinemia present with galactorrhoea
options.D: The drug of choice is Cabergoline

questions.explanation: All patients with hyperprolactinaemia do not present with galactorrhoea.Galactorrhoea is the secretion of milky fluid from the nipple which is unrelated to childbirth.Prolactin is the most important hormone involved in the pathophysiology of amenorrhoea andgalactorrhoea. Majority of women (80%) with high prolactin levels present with galactorrhoea.However, some hyperprolactinemic women may not have this symptom.Normal prolactin level is 25 ng/mL and levels more than this can cause galactorrhoea. Levels up to100 ng/mL occur in hyperprolactinaemia but prolactin level over 100 ng/mL is seen in pituitarytumours.Galactorrhoea is caused by pituitary adenoma and hyperprolactinemia. The condition isassociated with amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea and infertility. The drug of choice for thiscondition is cabergoline.669
